page.title: 10Local History to 1900
page.content: Local History Clovelly to 1900. {Clovelly Dykes,}marked with rings of banks and dykes, dates from the Iron Age. No evidence of permanent settlement has yet been found. The {Roman}name for Clovelly was Clausa Vallis, or closed valley. The{Saxon} name for Clovelly was Cleave Leigh, or wooded cleft. Clovelly is recorded in the 1086 Domesday Survey. The{Parish {Church}of All Saints dates from the Norman Period and was later extended in the Perpendicular period. The church is quite rich in monuments, many connected with the Lords of the Manor. The original and remaining wing of{Clovelly Court}possibly dates from the 14th Century. The{quay}and the present village houses of cob and stone with slate roofs date from the 16th Century.
